q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: How do citizens decide to vote in local elections? This is an important question in a political climate which partisanship characterizes national politics. Partisan disagreements at the federal level, can often lead to citizens’ interests not being realized. However at the same time, only about 10% of elected officials work at the federal level. If we change our perspective, much of the day- to-day operations of people’s lives are governed through local administrative bodies, run by local officials. To understand how citizens decide to elect such officials is increasingly an urgent and relevant research agenda. While there are scholars who argue that state politics has become more a function of national politics (Hopkins, 2018), we focus on even more local, sub-state politics. Here, we believe there are grounds to believe that citizen’s voting considerations are not simply a function of federal partisanship. Kuriwaki (2018), using ballot image records from South Carolina, finds people tend to vote less along party lines in super-local electoral positions such as County Council, Judicial, or Sheriff. Moskowtiz (2018) also suggests that local news coverage encourages voters to vote separately from their national party identification.

q16.value: I hypothesize that citizens in local elections are voting in an at-random fashion. As such giving citizens information about their candidates’ policy positions will affect how well they think the candidate voted for represents their interests. We are interested in the following subgroups for analysis and expect heterogeneous treatment affects in different combinations of the following groups: • Voters in the County Council (Partisan) Race and voters in the James Island Public Service District (Non-Partisan) Race • Voters who voted against their interest and voters who did not vote against their interest • Voters who split their ticket and voters who did not split their ticket My main variable of interest is the measured sense of regret for vote choice. We ask respondents, “How well do the candidates you voted for today represent your interests?”. Answers are given in 5 options: Perfectly, Well, Neither, Not well, Not at all Please refer to Pre Analysis Plan to for further detail.

q17.value: First, I will look at the cross table with percentages of different responses. I will use a chi- squared test to test the difference in distribution of answers among treatment and control groups in various subgroups. Second I will look at the bivariate relations between the treatment and outcome. This will be estimated by transforming the outcome into an indicator variable of whether a given category was chosen or not. I will use OLS, logit and probit with robust standard errors to estimate the change in probability that the outcome would be in a certain category k, when given treatment. Third, I will conduct regression analysis, but with controls. I will use the same OLS, Logit and Probit models. The motivation here is to generate results with smaller standard errors. The controls will be as shown in Table 2 of the Pre Analysis plan. Finally I will conduct an ordered logit and probit regression, treating the outcomes as ordered categorical variables. Like before, I will look at both bivariate relations and regression with controls. Here, the estimand is the direction of the coefficient(s). I want to know whether the treatment causes a positive or negative change in the predicted probability of moving from one category to another.

q19.value: About 1400 responses (non-responses included). Formal numbers wait digitization of results.

attributes.title: Pre-Analysis Plan for a Difference-in-Difference Design on Increasing Political Ambition and Efficacy in High School Students

q1.value: Pre-Analysis Plan for a Difference-in-Difference Design on Increasing Political Ambition and Efficacy in High School Students

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q16.value: Our principal hypothesis is that participation in the program we are studying will increase political ambition and efficacy. We will also examine whether there is an interaction between post-program political ambition and efficacy with gender. While we will report what we find, we are treating this matter as an open research question, not a directional hypothesis. See attached for further details.

q19.value: All participants in the program we are evaluating, which we expect to be around 1,000.

q27.value: Researchers, The program is administered by the Religious Action Committee.

q15.value: There is now a near consensus among researchers about the destructive consequences of corruption. In the light of this, measuring corruption has become a global industry, with leading actors like Transparency International and the World Bank spending millions of dollars on the construction of corruption indicators that rank the world's countries according to their quality of government. However, we still know little about the quality of many of these measures. This paper deploys a large survey experiment to investigate two potential sources of bias in indicators based on citizens' perceptions and experiences of corruption, stemming from political bias and sensitivity bias. First, I draw upon research on economic voting and argue that respondents are likely to respond in a political manner when asked how they perceive the level of corruption in their country. I test this argument by experimentally priming respondents' political affiliations before asking for their perception of corruption. Second, I argue that standard questions probing peoples' corruption experiences are likely to be subject to sensitivity bias. I test this second argument using by constructing a list experiment. Overall, the results will be of interest to organizations trying to measure corruption and for designers of questionnaires.

q16.value: H1a: On average, incumbent supporters will report lower perceived levels of corruption compared to opposition supporters. H1b: Increasing the salience of political affiliations will cause incumbent supporters to report even lower levels of corruption and opposition supporters to report even higher levels of corruption. H2: Reported experiences of corruption are subject to sensitivity bias and hence underreported.

q27.value: The survey will be administered by Luc.id

However, we still know little about the quality of many of these measures. This paper deploys a large survey experiment to investigate two potential sources of bias in indicators based on citizens' perceptions and experiences of corruption, stemming from political bias and sensitivity bias. First, I draw upon research on economic voting and argue that respondents are likely to respond in a political manner when asked how they perceive the level of corruption in their country. I test this argument by experimentally priming respondents' political affiliations before asking for their perception of corruption. Second, I argue that standard questions probing peoples' corruption experiences are likely to be subject to sensitivity bias. I test this second argument using by constructing a list experiment. Overall, the results will be of interest to organizations trying to measure corruption and for designers of questionnaires.

H1b: Increasing the salience of political affiliations will cause incumbent supporters to report even lower levels of corruption and opposition supporters to report even higher levels of corruption. H2: Reported experiences of corruption are subject to sensitivity bias and hence underreported.

attributes.title: Does Anger (Anxiety) Promote Support for Punitive (Protective) Immigration Policies? Study 2

q1.value: Does Anger (Anxiety) Promote Support for Punitive (Protective) Immigration Policies? Study 2

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Update to 20161019AA. I am adding a control condition that induces relaxation and counterbalancing outcomes and emotions measures based on reviewer feedback. The text is included below: We would like you to describe things about immigration that make you feel RELAXED. It is okay if you don't remember all the details, just be specific about what exactly it is that makes you RELAXED and what it feels like to be RELAXED. Please describe the events that make you feel the MOST RELAXED, these experiences could have occurred in the past or will happen in the future. If you can, write your description so that someone reading it might even feel RELAXED. We’d like you to take a moment to think about the debate over immigration in the United States. When you think about immigration what makes you feel RELAXED? Please list everything that comes to mind.

q16.value: H1: Assignment to the anger condition will produce support for punitive immigration policies, relative to the control and anxiety conditions. H2: Assignment to the anxiety condition will produce support for protective immigration policies, relative to the control and anger conditions.

q17.value: H1A: The effects of anger (anxiety) on punitive (protective) immigration policies will be strongest among conservatives. H2A: The effects of anger (anxiety) on punitive (protective) immigration policies will be strongest among authoritarians.

attributes.title: The Effects of Security Assistance on Recipient Militaries: Evidence From Liberia

q1.value: The Effects of Security Assistance on Recipient Militaries: Evidence From Liberia

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Security assistance between states has increased in scope and frequency as international efforts to bolster security forces in weak states have proliferated in recent years. Common foreign policy justifications for security assistance are that it transmits professional or democratic norms, increases recipient military effectiveness, and increases donor influence over the recipient force. However, empirical evidence is almost entirely lacking. This study investigates whether these hypothesized mechanisms are present in a case of extensive security assistance and, if present, whether the expected results obtain. First, I examine whether security assistance succeeds in imparting its purported normative and technical dimensions of military professionalism to the recipient force. Second, I examine how security assistance shapes the recipient force’s preference ordering when norms or interests come into conflict. For example, which norms are recipient forces more or less willing to sacrifice when faced with political or security dilemmas? Does the military’s decision-making calculus in such situations change with varying levels of exposure to foreign training and mentoring? Finally, when it comes to assisting militaries in weak states, can providers exert influence to make soldiers more compliant with otherwise unpopular or intrusive policies? I test these mechanisms with a representative survey of the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL), using embedded survey experiments. When Liberia’s civil war ended, it received a decade of multilateral and bilateral assistance to rebuild its security sector. The United States decided to disband the old AFL and rebuild it from scratch, which provides fertile ground for testing the effects of assistance; if any case could be expected to feature strong effects, it is Liberia. Importantly, there is variation within the AFL in terms of exposure to U.S. training and mentoring due to the nature of the U.S. program, which resulted in some soldiers receiving years of U.S. training and others receiving none.

q16.value: I evaluate three related sets of hypotheses: (1) The extent to which security assistance imparts the provider’s preference ordering over democratic norms. Second, whether tension between competing norms leads the military to make tradeoffs, choosing one norm over the other, or to avoid tradeoffs, choosing neither. (2) The extent to which types of security assistance that emphasize and reward merit—e.g., training, education, and mentoring—reduce neopatrimonial tendencies to award promotions for personal or political reasons. Second, whether forces with higher technical indicators of professionalism (merit-based advancement) report higher levels of morale, effectiveness, and cohesion. (3) The extent to which donor influence increases with high-contact forms of assistance such as training and mentoring. Specifically, whether the recipient military’s support increase for policies when they are sponsored by the dominant military partner. I also expect to see heterogeneous treatment effects based on economic status, tribal affiliation, education, and rank, with systematic differences between officers and enlisted soldiers. Finally, this study tests a series of non-experimental hypotheses about how exposure to different foreign military training (including African and Chinese militaries) correlates with outcome measures.

q17.value: These hypotheses are tested via three survey experiments embedded in a survey of the AFL, conducted in Liberia between December 4 – 15, 2017. First, a priming experiment examines how soldiers manage tradeoffs between competing democratic norms. The treatment is a vignette in which the military refuses a political order to repress protests, followed by a series of questions on attitudes about civil-military relations. Second, a list experiment uses indirect questioning techniques to elicit truthful reporting on the presence or absence of professionalism in the force. Finally, an endorsement experiment evaluates how support for intrusive rule-of-law policies varies when the United States, the African Union, or no one (control) is randomly assigned as a sponsor. All of the main effects are estimated using difference-in-means tests, and the treatment indicators are interacted with covariate measures of exposure to U.S. military training and mentorship.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Thermal comfort, that state of mind that expresses satisfaction with the thermal environment (ISO, 2005) is despite decades of research still not fully understood. Thermal comfort is directly related to energy consumption in buildings as space heating and cooling are used to maintain temperatures within a narrow band deemed comfortable from a mainly engineering orientated viewpoint. This study tests whether the emotional state of participants impacts on their thermal comfort perception.

q16.value: (1) Participants who recalled a happy life event feel warmer than those who recall a sad life event. (2) Participants who recalled a happy life event feel more comfortable than those who recall a sad life event. (3) Within the happy life event subgroup, those who feel happier also more comfortable. (4) With the sad life event subgroup, those who feel sadder also feel less comfortable.

q17.value: In a first step, I will check if the emotional manipulation has worked. On average, I would expect those having recalled a happy life event to feel happier than those who recalled a sad life, who on the other hand should feel sadder. However, given that the average is not informative for an individual’s experience, I will calculate the difference between the happy and sad emotion rating for each individual. For those who recalled a happy life event, I would expect a positive difference, i.e. a higher score on happy rating, for those who recalled a sad life event, I would expect a negative difference, i.e. a higher score on the sad rating. Participants whose answer to the emotional rating do not follow this pattern will be excluded as the experimental manipulation hasn’t worked. In addition, participants who wrote less than three sentences in their life event recall, will be excluded. Two linear regression analysis will be used to explain the values on the two comfort scores. The main predictor variable is having recalled a happy versus sad life events. For all covariates, age, gender, time spent in the UK, country of origin (transformed into Koeppen-Geiger climate classification), I will check if distribution varies between the group having recalled a happy vs. sad life even using Chi-Square tests for categorical variables, and t-tests for continuous variables. If distribution of the variables differs between the two groups, the variable will be used as covariate in above mentioned regression analysis. For the climate categorization, it is quite likely, that some categories might be very small. In that case, categories will be combined to arrive at a category size of at least 15 people. In addition, I will conduct regression analysis subgroup analysis within the happy and sad recall event group whereby the main predictor of interest is the strength of the happy and sad emotion rating.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: GOTV experiment to test the motivating effect of anti-Trump messaging among Democratic voters. Publication Agreement from Campaign: No publication until January 2021. Both the campaign and state will remain anonymous. At any time, the campaign could choose to lift the publication embargo sooner and/or remove the anonymity requirement.

q16.value: Is an anti-Trump GOTV message more effective than a placebo or a "best practices" script?

q17.value: There are 4 experimental conditions: placebo, best practices, Trump, and aspirational. All conditions start with a candidate support question. Only supporters are eligible for treatment. In analyzing the data, we will limit to units who meet the support qualification. We will then compare voter turnout rates across the two conditions, both with difference-in-means with t-tests and covariate-adjusted linear regression. Covariates are age general16 general14 general12 general10 general08 presprimary16 female afam white i.universe, where universe is a variable we used for blocking. Universe includes "NonVoter", "Sporadic Demotivated", "Sporadic Dropoff", and "Sporadic Possibile Base". We will look for heterogenous treatment effects by universe and by whether a voter is African American. For anything left unaddressed, we pre-commit to using the Green Lab SOP Version 1.05 at http://acoppock.github.io/Green-Lab-SOP/Green_Lab_SOP.pdf.

attributes.title: Fighting Corruption, Curbing Cynicism: The Public Opinion Consequences of Judicial Activism Against Corruption in Latin America

q1.value: Fighting Corruption, Curbing Cynicism: The Public Opinion Consequences of Judicial Activism Against Corruption in Latin America

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This survey experiment is part of a broader project that aims at assessing the impact of anti-corruption judicial activism on mass attitudes toward corruption and politics more generally. Does judicial accountability curb voters’ tolerance for corruption and political cynicism? Or do the investigation and punishment of corrupt politicians fuel cynicism about politics and the general crisis of trust in democratic institutions? Rather than adjudicating between these two possibilities, we are particularly interested in understanding the conditions under which anti-corruption activism may produce positive and mobilizing versus negative and demobilizing political attitudes. In this specific survey experiment, we test whether perceptions regarding two important features of the judicial fight against corruption drive attitudes toward politics and corruption. First, we assess the impact of perceptions regarding the procedural fairness of the judiciary in the fight against corruption. Second, we investigate whether perceptions of the judiciary’s effectiveness in the fight against corruption affect political attitudes. [CONTROL] Agora eu vou ler para você algumas informações sobre acontecimentos recentes da política Brasileira. Eu gostaria que você prestasse muita atenção. Em Maio de 2017 um grande escândalo de corrupção veio a tona e abalou a política Brasileira. Políticos de vários partidos—entre eles PMDB, PSDB e PT—foram acusados de receber milhões de reais em esquemas de corrupção. O escândalo foi resultado da Lava-Jato, uma grande operação contra a corrupção. [TREATMENT1 - EFFECTIVENESS] Agora eu vou ler para você algumas informações sobre acontecimentos recentes da política Brasileira. Eu gostaria que você prestasse muita atenção. Em Maio de 2017 um grande escândalo de corrupção veio a tona e abalou a política Brasileira. Políticos de vários partidos—entre eles PMDB, PSDB e PT—foram acusados de receber milhões de reais em esquemas de corrupção. O escândalo foi resultado da Lava-Jato, uma grande operação contra a corrupção. Você sabia que a atuação do Judiciário na lava-jato já levou a uma série de medidas e punições concretas contra os envolvidos em corrupção? De acordo com dados oficiais, a atuação do judiciário já levou a 165 condenações e conseguiu que mais de 4 bilhões de reais fossem devolvidos aos cofres públicos. [TREATMENT2 - PROCEDURAL FAIRNESS] Agora eu vou ler para você algumas informações sobre acontecimentos recentes da política Brasileira. Eu gostaria que você prestasse muita atenção. Em Maio de 2017 um grande escândalo de corrupção veio a tona e abalou a política Brasileira. Políticos de vários partidos—entre eles PMDB, PSDB e PT—foram acusados de receber milhões de reais em esquemas de corrupção. O escândalo foi resultado da Lava-Jato, uma grande operação contra a corrupção. Você sabia que as práticas investigatórias dos membros do Judiciário responsáveis pela lava-jato já receberam a aprovação da comunidade internacional? De acordo com informações oficiais, o judiciário recebeu vários prêmios nacionais e internacionais por adotar práticas investigatórias e condutas que, além de justas, são reconhecidas e respeitadas em todo o mundo.

q16.value: 1) When compared to individuals in the treatment condition (i.e., those who did not receive the information that the judicial anti-corruption effort has in fact produced concrete measures and punishments), individuals in the second condition (i.e., those who receive the information that the judicial anti-corruption effort has in fact produced concrete measures and punishments) will display: a. More positive emotions; b. Less cynicism; c. Less tolerance; d. Higher likelihood of protesting; e. Less support for outsiders; 2) When compared to individuals in the treatment condition (i.e., those who did not receive the information that the judicial anti-corruption effort follows fair and respectable procedures), individuals in the third condition (i.e., those who receive the information that the judicial anti-corruption effort has followed fair and respectable procedures) will display: a. More positive emotions; b. Less cynicism; c. Less tolerance; d. Higher likelihood of protesting; e. Less support for outsiders; 3) When compared to individuals in the third condition (i.e., those who receive the information that the judicial anti-corruption effort follows fair and respectable procedures), individuals in the second condition (i.e., those who receive the information that the judicial anti-corruption effort has in fact produced concrete measures and punishments) will display: a. More positive emotions; b. Less cynicism; c. Less tolerance; d. Higher likelihood of protesting; e. q17.value: Experiment embedded in a nationally representative survey of adults (+18) in Brazil

registration_responses.q1: Fighting Corruption, Curbing Cynicism: The Public Opinion Consequences of Judicial Activism Against Corruption in Latin America
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: This survey experiment is part of a broader project that aims at assessing the impact of anti-corruption judicial activism on mass attitudes toward corruption and politics more generally. Does judicial accountability curb voters’ tolerance for corruption and political cynicism? Or do the investigation and punishment of corrupt politicians fuel cynicism about politics and the general crisis of trust in democratic institutions? Rather than adjudicating between these two possibilities, we are particularly interested in understanding the conditions under which anti-corruption activism may produce positive and mobilizing versus negative and demobilizing political attitudes. In this specific survey experiment, we test whether perceptions regarding two important features of the judicial fight against corruption drive attitudes toward politics and corruption. First, we assess the impact of perceptions regarding the procedural fairness of the judiciary in the fight against corruption. Second, we investigate whether perceptions of the judiciary’s effectiveness in the fight against corruption affect political attitudes. [CONTROL] Agora eu vou ler para você algumas informações sobre acontecimentos recentes da política Brasileira. Eu gostaria que você prestasse muita atenção. Em Maio de 2017 um grande escândalo de corrupção veio a tona e abalou a política Brasileira. Políticos de vários partidos—entre eles PMDB, PSDB e PT—foram acusados de receber milhões de reais em esquemas de corrupção. O escândalo foi resultado da Lava-Jato, uma grande operação contra a corrupção. attributes.title: Land Titling as Social Cleavage in Malawi and Zambia

q1.value: Land Titling as Social Cleavage in Malawi and Zambia

q5.value: Funding from the Swedish Research Council

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: How does land titling -- the shift from informal to statutory systems of property rights -- impact community relations in countries where titling is in its infancy? While property rights and secure access to land are critical to rural livelihoods, we know less about how changes in property rights regimes transform village communities. Our research examines the social and political consequences of titling on cooperation within communities, which in turn have a variety of developmental implications. This is important, given the overwhelming focus on individual economic benefits of land titling. In much of Sub-Saharan Africa, citizens can secure their property rights through either customary or state institutions. We argue that households with a land title are less reliant on local customary institutions to access land; therefore, they are exempt from the customary institution’s rules and obligations. This can create important social divisions within a community as some are less beholden to and integrated into the community given that they sit outside the locally dominant customary institutions. We test this insight using a conjoint survey experiment to be implemented in Malawi and Zambia in May-July 2019, which allows us to address the central challenge of studying land titling: the endogenous uptake of land titling by certain populations. This study interrogates the unanticipated and heretofore ignored developmental consequences of land titling by focusing on its impacts on community relations.

q16.value: H1: Those who title their land will be seen with greater distrust by those who rely solely on customary property rights H2: Those who title their land will be seen as less cooperative by those who rely solely on customary property rights

q17.value: Using a survey experiment with citizens in rural Malawi and Zambia

q27.value: Researchers, Ubuntu Research in Zambia and IPOR in Malawi

attributes.title: How Political and Institutional Contexts Affect Behavioral Responses to Discrimination in the United States

q1.value: How Political and Institutional Contexts Affect Behavioral Responses to Discrimination in the United States

q9.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data from first phase of data collection AND prior to assignment of treatment/any data collection (for subsequent phases of data collection)

q15.value: A longstanding literature argues that systematic discretionary bias by bureaucrats can result in discrimination against citizens (who belong to a group that bureaucrats are systematically biased against, such as racial minorities, women, or members of the out-party) as well as downstream political, economic, and social inequalities (for a review of this literature see White, Nathan, and Faller 2015). Less well understood is how perceptions of bureaucratic bias, from the perspective of citizens, affects the conditions under which citizens belonging to different groups choose to engage in public policy behavior involving the state, such as applying for public benefits and approaching agents of the state to request constituent or public services (a notable exception is Lerman, Sadin, and Trachtman 2017). This study extends this nascent literature to assess how political and institutional contexts affect citizens' stated likelihood of engaging in public policy behavior, specifically the choice of whether to engage in legal mobilization in response to experiencing either race or sex discrimination, as well as alternative behavioral responses to being the target of discrimination.

registration_responses.q1: How Political and Institutional Contexts Affect Behavioral Responses to Discrimination in the United States
registration_responses.q9: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data from first phase of data collection AND prior to assignment of treatment/any data collection (for subsequent phases of data collection)

Less well understood is how perceptions of bureaucratic bias, from the perspective of citizens, affects the conditions under which citizens belonging to different groups choose to engage in public policy behavior involving the state, such as applying for public benefits and approaching agents of the state to request constituent or public services (a notable exception is Lerman, Sadin, and Trachtman 2017). This study extends this nascent literature to assess how political and institutional contexts affect citizens' stated likelihood of engaging in public policy behavior, specifically the choice of whether to engage in legal mobilization in response to experiencing either race or sex discrimination, as well as alternative behavioral responses to being the target of discrimination.
